BackBWSupineRow.name: Inverted Row
BackBWSupineRow.preparation: Lay on back under fixed horizontal bar. Grasp bar with wide overhand grip.
BackBWSupineRow.execution: Keeping body straight, pull body up to bar. Return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. Repeat.
BackBWSupineRow.comments: Fixed bar should be just high enough to allow arm to fully extend. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of body angle influences resistance. Also known as Body Row or Supine Row. Easier Resistance can be reduced by raising bar or sitting on hips. On HipsHigh Bar Harder Placing back of heels on elevated surface can make exercise slightly more challenging. This exercise is typically performed without added resistance, although additional weight can be placed on belly or pelvis. Feet ElevatedWeighted
BackBWSupineRow.synergists: latissimusdorsi, infraspinatus, brachioradialis, pectoralissternal, deltoidposterior, brachialis, trapeziusmiddle, teresmajor, trapeziuslower, teresminor, rhomboids

BackBWSupineRowFeetElevated.name: Inverted Row (feet elevated)
BackBWSupineRowFeetElevated.preparation: Lay on back under fixed horizontal bar. Grasp bar with wide overhand grip. Place back of heels on elevated surface.
BackBWSupineRowFeetElevated.execution: Keeping body straight, pull body up to bar. Return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. Repeat.
BackBWSupineRowFeetElevated.comments: Fixed bar should be just high enough to allow arm to fully extend. Placing back of heels on elevated surface is optional. This exercise is typically performed without added resistance, although additional weight can be placed on belly or pelvis. Partner can add and remove weight, and keep weight from sliding off belly. Resistance can be reduced by raising bar and positioning heels on floor. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of body angle influences resistance. Also known as Body Row or Supine Row. Easier Resistance can be reduced by placing feet on floor. Inverted Row Harder This exercise is typically performed without added resistance, although additional weight can be placed on belly or pelvis. Weighted
BackBWSupineRowFeetElevated.synergists: latissimusdorsi, infraspinatus, brachioradialis, pectoralissternal, deltoidposterior, brachialis, trapeziusmiddle, teresmajor, trapeziuslower, teresminor, rhomboids

BackBWSupineRowHigh.name: Inverted Row (high bar)
BackBWSupineRowHigh.preparation: Stand facing arms length away from waist to head height horizontal bar. Grasp bar with wide overhand grip. Position body under bar with legs, hips and spine straight. Arms should be straight, approximately perpendicular to body. Heels should make contact with floor.
BackBWSupineRowHigh.execution: Keeping body straight, pull body up to bar. Return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. Repeat.
BackBWSupineRowHigh.comments: Bar height can be adjusted to vary resistance. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of how body angle influences resistance. Also known as Body Row or Supine Row. Easier Resistance can be reduced by using higher bar or pivoting on hips with lower bar. On Hips Harder Lowering bar so body is closer to floor will make exercise more challenging. Inverted Row
BackBWSupineRowHigh.synergists: latissimusdorsi, infraspinatus, brachioradialis, pectoralissternal, deltoidposterior, brachialis, trapeziusmiddle, teresmajor, trapeziuslower, teresminor, rhomboids

BackBWSupineRowHips.name: Inverted Row (on hips)
BackBWSupineRowHips.preparation: Lay on back with belly under fixed horizontal bar. Bend knees and position feet on floor. Grasp bar with wide overhand grip.
BackBWSupineRowHips.execution: Keeping hips on floor and low back straight, pull torso up to bar. Return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. Repeat.
BackBWSupineRowHips.comments: Fixed bar should be just high enough to allow arm to fully extend. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of how body angle influences resistance. Also known as Body Row on Hips or Supine Row on Hips. Easier Resistance can be reduced by positioning torso at angle with hips further back. Also try straight body version on high bar. High Bar Harder Exercise will be more challenging when performing standard Inverted Row where entire body is pulled up, pivoting on back of heels. Inverted Row
BackBWSupineRowHips.synergists: latissimusdorsi, infraspinatus, brachioradialis, pectoralissternal, deltoidposterior, brachialis, trapeziusmiddle, teresmajor, trapeziuslower, teresminor, rhomboids

BackBWUnderhandSupineRow.name: Underhand Inverted Row
BackBWUnderhandSupineRow.preparation: Lay on back under fixed horizontal bar. Grasp bar with shoulder width underhand grip.
BackBWUnderhandSupineRow.execution: Keeping body straight, pull body up to bar. Return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. Repeat.
BackBWUnderhandSupineRow.comments: Fixed bar should be just high enough to allow arm to fully extend. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of how body angle influences resistance. Also known as Underhand Body Row or Underhand Supine Row. Easier Resistance can be reduced by raising bar or pivoting torso on hips instead of heels. High Bar Harder Placing back of heels on elevated surface can make exercise slightly more challenging. This exercise is typically performed without added resistance, although additional weight can be placed on belly or pelvis.
BackBWUnderhandSupineRow.synergists: latissimusdorsi, infraspinatus, brachioradialis, pectoralissternal, deltoidposterior, brachialis, trapeziusmiddle, teresmajor, trapeziuslower, teresminor, rhomboids

BackBWUnderhandSupineRowHigh.name: Underhand Inverted Row (high bar)
BackBWUnderhandSupineRowHigh.preparation: Stand facing arms length away from waist to head height horizontal bar. Grasp bar with shoulder width underhand grip. Position body under bar with legs, hips and spine straight. Arms should be straight, approximately perpendicular to body. Heels should make contact with floor with feet about perpendicular to legs.
BackBWUnderhandSupineRowHigh.execution: Keeping body straight, pull body up to bar. Return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. Repeat.
BackBWUnderhandSupineRowHigh.comments: Bar height can be adjusted to vary resistance. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of body angle influences resistance. Also known as Underhand Body Row or Underhand Supine Row. Easier Resistance can be reduced by using higher bar or pivoting on hips with lower bar. Harder Lowering bar so body is closer to floor will make exercise more challenging. Underhand Inverted Row
BackBWUnderhandSupineRowHigh.synergists: latissimusdorsi, infraspinatus, brachioradialis, pectoralissternal, deltoidposterior, brachialis, trapeziusmiddle, teresmajor, trapeziuslower, teresminor, rhomboids
